div.p: THE Life and Death of PHILIP HERBERT, the late Infamous Knight of Barkshire, once Earle of Pembrock, Moungomerie, &c. who departed from this Life to another January 23. 1640. Having, by a Degenerate basenesse, betrayed his Nobilitie; and entred himselfe a Commoner, amongst the vere Scum of the Kingdom.
LIKEWISE A Discourse with Charon in his Voyage to Hell.
WITH His Araignement, Tryall and Condemnation, before the three Judges, Aeacus, Minos and Raddamanthus.
Also the Entertainment and Welcome made by his Brethren, Pym, Dorislaus, Raynsborough, &c. with an ample testimonie of their Rejoycing at his Lordships Arivall.
PRINTED In the first yeere of PHIL. HARBERT'S Infernall-Captivity, and (I hope) the last of State-Tyranny.

div.l: TO Speake his life, it is below my Quill,
Nor can I think what his deserts, so ill,
Have merrited: but this, the trump of Fame,
Doth eccho forth, to him, eternall shame:
Each Babe and Suckling breathing out, that he
Hath left behind, Miriads of Infamie:
Posterity may curse the house, and name,
From whence so lewd a Member ever came.
If Treason had beene set aside, I might
Have writ him here an Earle▪ and not a Knight:
But, 't seems, his scorns were on the Earl so thrown;
His Honour's in the Dust; hee Knight alone
Could write, nor will I more
Ascribe unto him; though an Earle before
He was; High-Treason brought his Lordship down,
And made his Honour tumble with the Crown:
Nor had hee more of Honour, when hee dy'd,
Then in his life of Virtue could bee spy'd;
Which was so meane, that few, or none, will strive
By Panyg'ricks to keepe the Foole alive;
But since hee 's dead wee'll rather let him lye
In 's Grave a Traytor, as hee chose to dye;
So would I too, but this indeede I feare,
Infernall furies would 's Sepulchre teare
If men should bee so barren as to leave
So base a Traytor quiet in his Grave;
Therefore looke on the life which erst hee led,
A Servant to our King; hee dayly fed
Upon our Soveraignes bread, and might command
Well nigh what e're hee pleas'd, by Sea or Land:
The King so well did love him, that hee made
Him Court-Comptroler; yet hee Judas play'd,
And did betray his Master, by whose grace
Hee had his Titles, and enjoy'd his Place.
At first when Treason did begin to rage
Hee boldly entred on the Publique Stage:
Hee left his Royall Master, and did seeke
The rageing-Jewes, the Lamb betray so meeke:
No stratagem that e're his silly pate
Could hatch, but hee imploy'd it for the State:
When Lords had power, and did ith' Senate sit,
Yauling amongst the rest hee Lorded it;
But when hee found their pow'r fade and decay
Hee strove to bee the Commons Foole, and play
A Tragick part amongst those treach'rous Knaves
Who spil't their Soveraign's Blood, made 's Subjects Slaves:
Hee rather with a Tanner would compare,The Tanner might have had the place of Knight of Barkshire if he would have opposed.
Then in Rebellion not possesse a share;
Which having got, I think hee did not spare
Against both King and Cavalieres to sweare;
Cursing and daming, that not one should be
Left, but extirpated: His Tyrannie
So farre exceeded, that no Traytor there
But was asham'd such vi'lent words to heare;
This was his fatall day in which his vote
(Which of 't God-dam-him pass'd his bauling thoat)
Against those Loyall stemmes, who doe gain-say
To bow their knees to Baall, and obey
This Idoll Juncto and Rebellious State,
Whose damned Treasons Loyaltie must hate.
No sooner had this wasp shot out his sting
To kill both Cavaliere and Murther King;
But then his sinnes being ripe, hee had a Summons
To come to Hell amongst his brethren Commons;
And falling sick in a most dreadfull guise
With Swearing, Cursing, and with Blasphemies;
D • stractedly still calling out, the King,
The King! ô take him hence, or else hee'le bring
Me to my Grave! see where Hee stands!
This was his Death-Bed posture with his hands;
Beating and swearing till hee could not speake,
And then lay staring till grim Death did breake
His heart-strings, and from out this World
To Pim and Dorislaus his Knightship hurl'd,
Where now amongst Hells furies hee's bewayling
His former sinne, transgression, and his fayling.

div.head: PPILIP HERBERT'S Epitaph.
div.l: HE lies the Mirrour of our Age for Treason,
Who in his Life was void of Sence & Reason;
The Commons-Foole, a Knave in every thing;
A Traytor to his Master, Lord and King;
A man whose virtues were to Whore and Sweare;
God Dam him was his constant daily pray'r.

div.head: The Prologue.
div.l: THE Truth which wee in ancient Authors find,
'Tis better Thirsit's sonne with Hector's mind,
Then to bee Hector's sonne and Thirsit's like
To bee a bauling Coward and to strike,
Not daring, but degenerate from his birth,
Damne, Sweare and Rayle, not valluing breach of faith;
Such was the late Phil. Harbert who away
From 's Fathers Worth and Loyaltie did stray,
And shew'd himselfe a Thirsit in degree;
Nay, farre more base then Thirsit's e're could bee:
But I will leave to pourtraict him, and tell
His Voyage, Tryall, and his State in Hell.

div.head: A Discourse between Philip Herbert and Charon, at the River of Acheron, and in his Voyage to the Port of Hell.
div.stage: Enter Philip Herbert, at the side of Acheron, calling Charon.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.l: SO Ho, so ho! Zbood Come Charon, come away, delay me not,
I haste to bee at the Port, where I
May keep my brother-Rebells company.

sp.speaker: Charon.
sp.p: Feare not, brave Champion, thou shalt have no delay; my Boat 's both rig'd and trim'd, Ile quickly waft thee.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: O come prithee, Dam mee, the time passeth away very swift; Let mee not lose this Tyde.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p:
Ile not neglect thee, No, without all doubt, thou wilt find the time long enough,
'Tis to Eternity, when once th 'art in
Thou wilt be kept close-Prisoner for thy Sin.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: Eternity! Sin! Zbood what are those? I know them not. Sinke me! Z • unds! can a Parliament man commit Sin? No, no sure hee cannot.

sp.speaker: Cha,
sp.l: Your Lordship is mistaken in Parliament men,
Who, as the Case now stands
Act, altogether, against God's-Commands.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p:
Judge me! Like enough! for I never thought three times of God these eight yeeres,
Nor did I ever think there was a need
Remember God, or to repeat my Creed.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: I know it Sir,
For which, Hell is prepar'd and, you must frie
In Sulphry flames, for Treas'n & Perjurie.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Rot mee, if your sport bee so hot
Ile goe from whence I came, I like it not.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: No Sir; it is too late to Repent,
I have obey'd your Call
And you must goe; it is in vain at all
T' attempt Escape, I 've Legions at Command,
Who soon will seiz, and bind you foot and hand.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p:
A Pox on't, Ile pay thee well if thou wilt let mee Escape and goe back to Whitehall
For Truth I find
That Hell will both Torment Body and Mind.

div.stage: One foote in the Boate he leapt back again on Shoare.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: 'Tis true indeed Sir, and you must
Have your Deserts, your punishment is just;
Then step into the Boat, I cannot stay,
Some other Fare will come, Let's haste away.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: Zounds, why so hastie? Stay a little; though I was in hast at the first and ran headlong, now (perceiving what I must suffer) I can well spare a little time.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Yes, but the time's ore-past and th' Furies houle
To be a gnawing thy Blood-stayned-Soule,
There's no remedy then, nor can I so
Much freedom grant that back again thou goe.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: A Plague on thee then, Take me to the Devill and spare not,
I hope I shall be Comrade with Dorislaus.
My Misery will be abated, some Reliefe
'T will be to have Co-partners in my Griefe.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p:
Wee shall be there quickly Sir, I have no more to doe but only to deliver you over to Cerberus,
Then get of him what Terms you can or may.
You will not long, I'm sure, for Sentence stay.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: May! Zoood What May dost thou meane?
If my deere Mistres the Lady May be here
To burne in thousand Hells I will not feare.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: No, no, it is not shee by may I meane; get what freedom you can untill your Arraignment and Triall be past, 'tis that I meane.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: The Devill take thee! Judge me!
I had strong hopes the Lady May had been before
To keep mee Company and bee my Wh—.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: There are Hounds (and please you Sir plenty) which will barke and baule to purpose when your Lordship comes a little neerer.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: Dam mee, I like the noyse deerely; I alwaies lov'd Hunti • g well: But preethee what stinke of Brimstone and Burning is this?

q.l: Which doth arise from the Abysse of Hell.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: No my Lord, this is but small to the stink when you are in;
But hold now Cerberus barks, wee must leave talking.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: Sinke mee, there's a D • mn'd noyse indeed; If this bee a Hell-hound I like not the Musick.

sp.speaker: Cer.
sp.l: O Charon, who is there? What hast thou brought?
Is that an English Statesman thou hast caught?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I hee 's come from England, his name was Pembroke, one of our chiefe Champions: For Damming, Sinking, Swearing & Cursing, all the Inhabitants of Hell can hardly equal him.

sp.speaker: Cerb.
sp.p: Well then Charon on thy report Ile entertain him, If 't bee Herbert, I have waited for him these many yeeres.

q.l: Farewell Charon, help mee with some more,
I fain would fill my Goale with English Store.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Adieu my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.p: Zblood art thou gone? Farwell and be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Cer,
sp.l: Come, walk with mee, and Ile thy Lordship bring
Where Judas is, that first betray'd his King.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.p: With all my heart, I 'de fain shake hands with him.
sp.stage: He draws neere and the Damned houle.
sp.p:
Dam me! What noyse is this? fough they stinke, is Atkins here, or have they beshit themselves? A pox take um they'll Poyson mee,
I'le not goe amongst them; this place is much too hot,
I'le have a cooler if it can bee got.

sp.speaker: Cer.
sp.l: No such matter Sir,
This was provided for you, and this place
Must bee your lodging, till great Pluto's Grace
Appoint your Triall, which will bee to morrow,
And then your Doom will bee eternall-Sorrow.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.p: The Devill grace him, if it must be so, it shall be so; Oh, oh▪ oh! Zblood, Zounds, Dam mee and Sink me!

q.l: Woe, woe, woe, woe, My Pains begin,
I feele the Torment due unto my Sin.

div.stage: Enter Pym, Hamden, two Hothams, Essex, Raynsborough, Dorislaus, Brookes, Jones. &c. all houling & wayling.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.p: Zblood whats the matter men, all mad?
The Devill 's in you I think, no better welcome? All weeping and mourning as black as Hell.

sp.speaker: All the Reb.
sp.l: Best welcom we can give to thee 's to tell
Thou must tormented bee with us in Hell.

sp.speaker: Pem,
sp.p: You doe not know that till I have been Tried.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: That will bee quickly done.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.p: May I chuse Councell?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Yes, yes, You may.

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.l: Dam-me then, because they know the Lawes,
My Councell shall bee Pim and Dorislaus.

div.stage: The three Judges being set Gerberus comes with the black-guard to carry Pembroke to the Barre.
Enter Aeachus, Minos and Raddamanthus in Chayres. Pembrokes Charge is read.

sp.speaker: Clarke.
sp.p: You Philip Harbert once Earle of Pembroke, but late one of the Commons of Westminster, stand charged of these following Crimes and Inormities: Perjury, Treason, Murther, Adultery, Blasphemy, Swearing, Cursing, Fornication, Rebellion, Sacriledge, Tyrannie, with innumerable more of the like nature, as Drunkenesse, &c. whether are you guilty or not guilty? what can you say for your selfe, why you should not suffer eternall punishment amongst your brothers, Pim. Hambden, Brooks. &c.
What say you? guilty, or not guilty?

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.p: 'Zlood I cannot plead, will you allow mee Councell?

sp.speaker: Judg.
sp.p: Heer's no Councell, here we are both Judg and Councell; Plead quickly, or wee proceed to Sentence, what say'st thou?

sp.speaker: Pem.
sp.p: Judge me: Sink me I know not what to say more, but that I alwayes did what your spirit of wickednesse prompted. I think I've beene Hells friend indeede.

q.l: That e're from Sathans Law I turn'd away.

sp.speaker: Judges.
sp.p: 'Tis true, therefore receive thy pay.
Raddamanthus passeth sentence and commits Pembroke to Megaera, Alecto, and Tesiphone.

sp.speaker: Radda.
sp.p: By the power of Lucifer great Prince of this infernall Abysse, &c. you are to take the Soule of Philip Harbert prisoner at the Barre, and dispose it into Lethe, first Carbona doing and broyling him upon the Coales, and then in the coldest Lake tumble him; yet not ceasing, give him boyling lead for drink, with all the greatest tortures that Hell can imagine, thus using your greatest skill in tormenting him, let not his misery cease to eternity, as you tender the displeasure of your chiefe Prince and Ruler.
sp.stage: The three furies lay hold on him, and hale him head-long into Hell fire.

q.l: Hee houles and cryes, curses and sweares,
Whil'st his tormentors rayne infernall snares
Upon him, making him to quaffe
Full boules oth' Stigian-Lake, whil'st they doe laugh
At his Damnation, and are glad
That in their hands they've got the dam-me Lad.

div.head: The Epilogue.
div.l: PEMBROCK in Hell, with grievous Sighs and Groanes
Doth Eccho forth eternall Woes and Moanes
Unto the Furies, and with gummy teares
Attempts to penetrate their deafned eares;
But, all in vain, they stop not to torment him,
It was too late (when once in Hell) Repent him;
Nor can hee e're get out, eternally
Within those Sulph'ry-flames his Soule must fry;
If all our Regicides were with him there,
Thrice happy, happy, then this England were.
